title: How to Landscape

steps.headline: Set a budget for your landscape.
steps.description: Landscaping can be a costly project, especially if you’re doing your entire yard. List the things you really want to include in your yard or things that you need to repair and look around to see how much they cost. Aim to save between $5,000-$10,000 USD or 10% of your home’s value or to put towards your landscaping. Work on landscaping a little bit at a time if you don’t want to spend a lot of money at once. Consider reusing some of the plants or objects already in your yard to cut the costs of your project. Save an additional 10% to your expected costs in case something demands more budget.

steps.headline: Draw a “floor plan” on graph paper so you can plan your landscape to scale.
steps.description: Make each square on your graph paper equal to 1 square foot (0.093 m). Draw the shape of your yard as accurately as you can. Use a pencil to mark squares and circles for where you want to put plants or fixtures. Keep in mind where the sun is throughout the day and where any utility lines run so you can plan plants around them. Look for a landscape design program on your computer to work on your landscape digitally. Good free programs to use include Home Outside, Gardena, and Marshalls Garden Visualiser. Visit your local landscaping store to see what you want to include in your yard. Look on Pinterest or other online sources for more ideas on how to landscape your yard.

steps.headline: Use geometric shapes and hardscaping for a contemporary look.
steps.description: Keep the lines between hardscapes, like paths and patios, and your plants clear and straight. Incorporate squares and rectangles into your design, such as a long straight path leading to an open rectangular patio. Pick out plants that are easy to prune so you can easily change their shape, like boxwoods, cedars, or succulents. Contemporary landscapes require a lot of plant care so they are controlled and confined to their area.

steps.headline: Use gravel paths and native plant life for a naturalistic landscape.
steps.description: Let your plant life thrive in your yard and garden seem more natural. Look at forests and woodlands for inspiration while planning out your landscaping. If you want to include paths or patios, use stones or gravel in curved lines to draw more attention to your plants. Include simple features, like bird baths or small stone structures, to add more visual interest. Let areas of your yard run wild if you want minimal upkeep in your yard.

steps.headline: Consider adding berms to your yard to change elevation.
steps.description: Berms are small raised hills that you can put in your yard to add visual interest and elevation to your yard. Place your berms in corners of your yard or along one of your plot lines. Make a pile of soil so that’s 5 times as long as it is tall to form your berm. Pat it down on top with a shovel and plant any vegetation you want before covering the berm in 2–3 inches (5.1–7.6 cm) of mulch. Avoid putting berms near your home so runoff water doesn’t pool against the structure.

steps.headline: Plant trees first.
steps.description: Trees are the largest parts of your landscape and should be prioritized so you can plan around them. Choose a place in your yard where your tree will fit once it’s reached its full size. Pick up a young tree from your local nursery so it’s easier to transport and plant. Dig a hole slightly wider and deeper than the tree’s root system and put your tree in the ground. Water the tree every day for the first 3-4 weeks so it can establish roots. Tie the tree trunk to stakes to help it grow straight and prevent wind from blowing it over. Choose evergreen trees if you want shade in your yard throughout the entire year. Pick deciduous trees that lose their leaves yearly if you just need shade in the summer.

steps.headline: Roll sod across your lawn if you don’t want to grow grass.
steps.description: Sod is pre-grown grass that’s rolled up and easy to lay in your yard. After measuring your yard and determining how much sod you need, lay it down along the edges of your yard first. Work in a brick-like pattern until your entire yard is covered. You may need to cut pieces of sod to fit around curves or obstacles already present in your yard. Look at the nearest landscaping store to see what types of grasses they offer.

steps.headline: Choose a color theme for your plants to create a specific mood in your yard.
steps.description: Color themes create a mood for your yard. Use warm-colored plants, like those that are red or orange, to add warmth and excitement to your yard. If you want a more relaxing space, choose plants with cool colors, like blue, white, and pink. Make sure to choose similarly colored plants for your entire yard so it’s completely cohesive. For example, you may plant sunflowers, zinnias, and petunias to create a warm color scheme.

steps.headline: Put in plants that naturally grow in your area if you want a low maintenance yard.
steps.description: Go to a plant nursery or landscaping store and ask them what plants are native to your local climate. That way, all you have to do is plant them in your yard and provide minimal watering and upkeep. If you’re working on a budget, native plants tend to be cheaper to maintain than other plants. For example, if you live in a hot, arid climate, avoid planting anything that requires a lot of water. Instead, look for succulents or cacti for your yard. Native plants require less watering since they’re already used to their climate.

steps.headline: Vary the heights of your plants to add visual interest.
steps.description: Use shorter flowering plants around the inner edges of your landscaping. Plant tall decorative shrubs or grasses behind them so they don’t block your view of your shorter plants. Put tall plants in corners to add another visual pop! Mix decorative grasses, like fountaingrass or feather reedgrass, with ground cover plants, like lamb’s ear or impatiens.

steps.headline: Use plants with different leaf shapes and textures to add variety to your yard.
steps.description: Combine beds of smaller, flowering plants with leafier, upright plants to create visual interest. Put plants with different leaf shapes next to one another so they contrast and stand out. Even if they have different leaf shapes and textures, avoid putting plants that are the same color next to one another. Otherwise, you won’t be able to easily tell them apart. For example, you may put lamb’s ear, which has smooth round leaves, next to more textured plants like ferns, that have large, textured leaves.

steps.headline: Put in a patio if you want a space to entertain.
steps.description: Patios can be made a variety of sizes and out of multiple materials. Think about how you want to use your patio and how many people it needs to fit during the design stages. Once you have an idea of what you want to do, build the shape of your patio with bricks, pavers, or concrete. Keep an outdoor-safe table on your patio if you want an exterior dining space. Consider a covered patio if you want it to be a relaxing space in the shade.

steps.headline: Place lights around your yard to illuminate it.
steps.description: Lights will make your outdoor space beautiful even at night! Look for solar-powered lights so you don’t need to run wires through your yard. Put the lights around pathways so guests can see where they’re walking or use floodlights to illuminate a prominent piece of your landscaping, such as a sculpture or large plant. Outdoor lighting can be purchased at any home and garden store. If you want lighting that you can control with a switch, hire a landscaping specialist to help run wires underground.

steps.headline: Consider putting in a fence if you want privacy.
steps.description: Measure along the perimeter of your yard so you know how much fencing you need to buy. Use wooden panel fences that are about 6 feet (1.8 m) tall so it’s not easy for others to look or climb over. Hedges are tall shrubs that make great natural barriers between your and your neighbor’s yard. Check with your city to see if you can build a fence in your neighborhood.

steps.headline: Put a fountain in your yard for visual interest.
steps.description: Remove all the topsoil in the area where you want to place your feature. Make sure the base layer is level and packed tight with stone dust. Set the base on top of your packed stone dust and use a level to make sure it sits flat. Feed the pump line through the fountain and fill the fountain with water. Use a solar-powered pump so you don’t have to run electrical wires underground. Look for a fountain that fits the style of your landscaping. Browse landscaping stores to find a fountain that’s right for you.

steps.headline: Build decorative garden walls to make raised planting beds.
steps.description: Plan out where you want to build your walls. Dig a trench that’s twice as deep as the width of your walls. Fill the trench in with sand and rocks to make a sturdy and level base. Lay the first layer of stones on top of the sand, making sure each of your stones is level. As you build your walls up, fill in the back side with rocks, gravel, or another well-draining medium. Plant shrubs and flowers in the area closed off by your wall to make your plants seem taller.
